threats.title: Compromised Artifacts
threats.description: During the CI Pipeline Execution, if artifacts are not properly secured, they could be tampered with or altered. This could lead to the deployment of compromised, insecure, or malicious artifacts.
threats.mitigation:
Access Control: Implement strict access control measures to ensure that only authorized personnel can access and modify pipeline artifacts.

Artifact Integrity Verification: Use checksums or digital signatures to verify the integrity of artifacts before and after storage. Tools like GPG (GNU Privacy Guard) can be helpful.

Code Signing: Ensure artifacts are signed before they are stored. Verify these signatures during the deployment process to guarantee they haven't been tampered with.

Isolated Environments: Run CI/CD jobs in isolated, ephemeral environments to minimize the risk of artifacts being compromised during execution.

Comprehensive Logging: Maintain detailed logs of all actions taken during CI Pipeline Execution. Regularly review these logs to identify any suspicious activities.

Regular Security Audits: Conduct regular security audits of the CI/CD pipeline and artifact storage to identify and address any vulnerabilities.

threats.title: Bypassing Security Gates
threats.description:
If there are weaknesses or misconfigurations in the CI pipeline execution, it may bypass critical security checks or gates, allowing vulnerable or malicious code to pass through without proper scrutiny.

Potential deployment of insecure or compromised applications, leading to security breaches, data loss, or service interruptions.
threats.mitigation:
Enforce Strict Security Policies: Implement and enforce strict security policies and procedures to ensure that security gates cannot be bypassed.

Automated Security Checks: Integrate automated security checks at multiple stages of the CI pipeline to catch vulnerabilities early. Tools like OWASP ZAP, Brakeman, or Nessus can be useful.

Manual Reviews: Perform manual code and configuration reviews, especially for critical changes, to ensure no security gates are circumvented.

Role-Based Access Control (RBAC): Use RBAC to restrict who can modify the CI pipeline configuration or disable security checks.

Audit Trails: Maintain comprehensive audit trails for all CI pipeline executions to detect and investigate any instances of bypassed security gates.

Continuous Monitoring: Implement continuous monitoring and alerting for any deviations from the expected pipeline execution process.

threats.title: Security Gate Misconfiguration
threats.description:
If the security gate is misconfigured or not functioning correctly, it can lead to improper validation of security policies. This could allow vulnerable or malicious code to be built, signed, and published.

Deployment of compromised or insecure images, leading to potential security breaches, data loss, or service disruptions.
threats.mitigation:
Rigorous Testing and Validation:

Regularly test and validate the security gate configurations to ensure they are functioning as intended.

Use automated testing frameworks to continually verify security policies.

Configuration Management:

Use configuration management tools like Ansible, Puppet, or Chef to manage and verify security gate settings.

Implement version control for security gate configurations to track changes and ensure proper rollback mechanisms.

Monitoring and Alerting:

Implement continuous monitoring and alerting for the security gate to detect misconfigurations or failures in real-time.

Use tools like Prometheus and Grafana for monitoring and alerting purposes.

Role-Based Access Control (RBAC):

Use RBAC to ensure that only authorized personnel can modify security gate configurations.

Enforce the principle of least privilege to minimize the risk of unauthorized changes.

Audit Logs and Reviews:

Maintain comprehensive audit logs for all security gate activities.

Conduct regular reviews and audits of security gate configurations and logs to identify potential issues.

threats.title: Malicious Image Upload
threats.description:
If the build, sign, and publish stage produces and uploads a malicious or compromised image, it could lead to DockerHub serving these compromised images. This can potentially cause security breaches for anyone using these images.

Unauthorized access, data breaches, service disruptions, and the spread of malicious software through widely-used container images.
threats.mitigation:
Code Signing:

Ensure that all images are signed with cryptographic keys before publishing.

Validate these signatures during deployment to ensure integrity and authenticity.

Isolated Build Environments:

Use isolated and secure build environments to prevent unauthorized access and ensure only trusted code is built and signed.

Regular Security Scans:

Implement regular security scans on images before they are published. Tools like Anchore, Clair, or Trivy can be useful for this.

Access Controls:

Implement strict access controls for the build and publish processes. Only authorized personnel should be able to modify and publish images.

Audit Logging:

Maintain detailed audit logs of all build, sign, and publish activities. This helps in detecting unauthorized actions and understanding the chain of events in case of a breach.

Continuous Monitoring:

Continuously monitor the container repository for any signs of tampering or unauthorized access.

Implement alerts for any suspicious activities.

threats.title: Malicious Code Injection
threats.description:
Malicious code or vulnerabilities could be introduced during the code push process. If the code being pushed is not thoroughly reviewed or scanned, it may contain malware, backdoors, or other security issues.

Compromise the integrity of the Git repository and potentially the entire CI/CD pipeline.
threats.mitigation:
Code Reviews: Enforce mandatory code reviews before any code is merged into the main branch. This ensures multiple sets of eyes check for potential issues or malicious code.

Automated Scanning: Implement static code analysis and security scanning tools like SonarQube, Checkmarx, or Veracode as part of your CI pipeline to detect vulnerabilities and security issues automatically.

Pre-commit Hooks: Use pre-commit hooks to run security checks and enforce coding standards before the code is pushed to the repository.

Access Controls: Restrict write access to the repository only to trusted developers and enforce the principle of least privilege.

Continuous Monitoring: Implement continuous monitoring of the CI/CD pipeline to detect any suspicious activities or anomalies.

Audit Logs: Maintain detailed audit logs of all code pushes and repository changes to facilitate forensic analysis and detect unauthorized modifications.

Secure Developer Environments: Ensure that developers' environments are secure by using up-to-date software, strong authentication, and endpoint protection.

threats.title: Pipeline Poisoning
threats.description:
If malicious code is pushed during the code push process, it can manipulate the build or deployment process in the CI pipeline. This could lead to unauthorized changes, deployment of compromised applications, or even complete pipeline disruption.

Unauthorized deployment, compromised application integrity, potential data breaches, and service disruptions.
threats.mitigation:
Access Controls: Implement strong access control measures. Use role-based access control (RBAC) to ensure only authorized personnel can push code.

Code Reviews: Enforce mandatory peer code reviews before code is merged into the main branch to catch any malicious alterations.

Static Analysis: Integrate static code analysis tools to automatically scan for potential vulnerabilities or malicious code.

Pipeline Integrity Verification: Use cryptographic signatures to verify the integrity of the code and dependencies at various stages of the pipeline.

Isolated Execution: Ensure that CI jobs run in isolated environments to limit the impact of any malicious code execution.

Audit Logs: Maintain comprehensive audit logs for all actions within the CI pipeline to facilitate detection and forensic analysis of unauthorized activities.

threats.title: Dependency Repository Compromise
threats.description: If the Dependency Repository is compromised, it could inject malicious or vulnerable dependencies into the CI pipeline, affecting the "Fetch dependencies" and "CI pipeline execution" stages.
threats.mitigation:
Dependency Integrity Verification:

Implement checksums or digital signatures for all dependencies and verify them before use.

Use tools like npm audit or yarn audit to check for known vulnerabilities in dependencies.

Use Trusted Sources:

Only fetch dependencies from trusted and verified repositories.

Regularly audit and update the list of trusted sources.

Automated Security Scanning:

Integrate automated security scanning tools in the CI pipeline to detect and block malicious dependencies.

Use tools like Snyk, Dependabot, or WhiteSource for continuous monitoring of dependencies.

Access Control:

Restrict access to the Dependency Repository to authorized personnel only.

Implement role-based access control (RBAC) to limit who can add or modify dependencies.

Regular Audits:

Conduct regular security audits of the Dependency Repository.

Monitor logs for any suspicious activity related to dependency fetching and usage.

threats.title: Compromised Developer Environment
threats.description:
If a developer's environment is compromised, an attacker could inject malicious code into the Git push. This code could then get integrated into the CI pipeline.

Potential deployment of vulnerable or malicious applications, data breaches, and compromised system integrity.
threats.mitigation:
Authentication: Ensure robust authentication mechanisms for developers' Git access, like multi-factor authentication (MFA).

Code Reviews: Mandatory code reviews to catch any injected malicious code before merging.

Automated Security Scans: Implement automated security scans, like static code analysis and dependency checks, to detect vulnerabilities and malicious code.

Audit Logs: Maintain detailed logs of all Git pushes and CI activities for forensic analysis and monitoring.

threats.title: Developer pushes a secret to the Git repository
threats.description: If sensitive information like API keys, passwords, or tokens are pushed to the repository, they can be accessed by unauthorized individuals, leading to potential security breaches.
threats.mitigation:
Here are some steps to mitigate the risk: Exposed Secrets

Secret Management: Use secret management tools like Azure Key Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, or HashiCorp Vault to store and access sensitive information securely.

Scanning Tools: Implement automated secret scanning tools like GitGuardian, TruffleHog, or Gitleaks in your CI pipeline to detect and prevent accidental secret leaks.

Environment Variables: Use environment variables to inject secrets during runtime rather than hardcoding them.

threats.title: Insufficient Pipeline-Based Access Controls (PBAC)
threats.description: If access controls are not properly implemented, malicious code or secrets can be pushed to production without proper review or approval
threats.mitigation:
Role-Based Access Control (RBAC): Implement RBAC to restrict access to the CI/CD system based on user roles and responsibilities.

Auditing and Logging: Enable comprehensive logging and auditing of all CI/CD activities to detect and respond to unauthorized access attempts.

threats.title: Poisoned Pipeline Execution (PPE)
threats.description: Malicious code or commands injected into the build process can manipulate the pipeline, allowing threat actors to run malicious code during the build process
threats.mitigation:
Code Reviews: Enforce mandatory code reviews before merging code changes to detect any malicious changes.

Signature Verification: Use digital signatures to verify the integrity of code and dependencies used in the pipeline.

Isolated Execution: Run CI/CD jobs in isolated and ephemeral environments to limit the impact of any malicious code execution.

threats.title: Insecure System Configuration
threats.description: Misconfigurations in the CI/CD system can be exploited by attackers to gain unauthorized access to sensitive information
threats.mitigation:
Configuration Management: Use configuration management tools like Ansible, Puppet, or Chef to ensure consistent and secure system configurations.

Vulnerability Scanning: Regularly scan the CI/CD system for vulnerabilities using tools like Nessus, Qualys, or OpenVAS.

Patch Management: Keep all software and dependencies up-to-date with the latest security patches.

threats.title: Dependency Chain Abuse
threats.description: Malicious code or dependencies can be introduced into the pipeline, affecting the integrity of the build process and potentially compromising the application
threats.mitigation:
Dependency Management: Use dependency management tools like Dependabot, Renovate, or Snyk to monitor and update dependencies regularly.

Reputable Sources: Only use dependencies from reputable and trusted sources, and verify their integrity using checksums or digital signatures.

Immutable Builds: Create immutable builds that capture and lock the state of dependencies at a specific point in time, reducing the risk of introducing malicious changes.
